data.statement: Framing a build as a postmortem with a numbered mistake count (e.g., ‚ÄúTwo Mistakes‚Äù) significantly boosts performance on this channel by combining vulnerability (‚Äúmistakes‚Äù) with specificity (a number) and a familiar build context, increasing curiosity and perceived learning value.
data.reasoning: The title pairs a trusted persona (Adam Savage) and a known build context with a negative/contrarian hook (‚Äúmistakes‚Äù) and numeral specificity (‚ÄúTwo‚Äù), which typically raises CTR via curiosity (‚Äúwhat went wrong?‚Äù) and promises actionable insights (‚Äúhow to avoid these errors‚Äù). This ‚Äòmistake-focused case study‚Äô format likely contrasts with standard showcase/how-to titles, creating novelty and higher perceived utility. The numbered-mistake framing also implies a concise, structured payoff, improving watch intent. Prior creator analytics often show lift from vulnerability/‚ÄòI was wrong‚Äô titling; on Tested‚Äôs audience of makers, mistake deconstructions are high-relevancy learning content, plausibly driving TPS well above baseline.
